front.head: This cast list has been adapted from the 1679 folio edition of Beaumont and Fletcher's Fifty Comedies and Tragedies. Spelling has been regularized based on how names appear in the dialogue, and new descriptions have been supplied.

div.stage: Enter Rosella, Clarinda, Crocale, Juletta, and Hippolita.

lg.l: I am deaf to all your entreaties. She that moves me
For pity or compassion to these pirates
Digs up her father's or her brother's tomb,
And spurnsspurns: kicks about their ashes.
Couldst thou remember what a father thou hast once,
'Twould steel steel: harden thy heart against foolish pity.
By his memory, and the remembrance of his dear embraces,
I am taught that in a noble noble: fine cause revenge is noble noble: fine,
And they shall fall fall: fall prey to, become victims of the sacrifices to appease
His wandering ghost, and my incensed fury.
The new-come prisoner, too?
Him, too. Yet that we may learn
Whether they are the same, or near allied
To those that forced me to this cruel course,
Better their poor allowance Better their poor allowance: Provide them more sustenance, and permit 'em
To meet together and confer confer: converse, speak
Within the distance of your ear. Perhaps
They may discover something that may kill
Despair in me and be a means to save 'em
From certain ruin.
That shall be my chargecharge: responsibility; also, burden.
Yet to prevent
All hope to rescue—for this new-come captain
Hath both a ship and men not far off from us,
Though ignorant to find the only port
That can yield entrance to our happy island—
Guard the place strongly, and ereere: before the next sun
Ends his diurnal diurnal: occupying the length of one day progress, I will be
Happy in my revenge, or set 'em free.

div.stage: Enter Crocale, Juletta, and Hippolita, with a table, food, and wine.
div.note: In early modern drama, a table itself as a prop could be considered an extravagant display considering set design tended to be minimalistic. Money spent by theater companies was invested more in costumes than sets. As a result, plays during the period had remarkably spare stages, requiring the audience to rely heavily on their imagination to furnish the setting. Seeing a table furnished with lots of props would likely stand out to the audience, and suggests that the table will be the center of gravity for the scene. In other words, the action will revolve around the table, directly and indirectly.

lg.l: So serve it plentifully,
And lose not time to enquire the cause;
There is a main main: powerful designdesign: plot that hangs hangs: depends upon this bounty bounty: i.e. the food and wine.
See the table furnishedfurnished: provided with wine, too;
That discovers secrets which tortures cannot open open: reveal.
Open the doors, too, of the several prisons,
And give all free entrance into this room.
Undiscovered, I can here markmark: watch all.
lg.note: In the original text, no stage directions are provided to indicate Crocale is hiding or has stepped aside. Additionally, no stage directions specify that Hippolita and Juletta exit. Rather, these actions must simply be inferred from the dialogue. During this period, performances accomplished hiding characters in several ways. In the Blackfriars Theatre, for example, Crocale could 'hide' by sitting with the audience, as some of the audience in the Blackfriars sat on the side of the stage. Another place for Crocale to hide could be up on a balcony (which many early modern theaters had), watching the action from up above. The most important aspect of this stage direction is possibly not that Crocale is visible to the audience, but that the audience actually knows she is hiding.
lg.l: Here's Captain Careless, and the tough shipmaster.
The slaves are nosed like vulturesnosed like vultures: i.e. scavenging;
How wild they look—
Ha, the mystery of this,
Some good hobgoblin hobgoblin: mischievous spirit or being; can also refer to characters from folklore such as Robin Goodfellow rise and reveal!
I am amazed at it, nor can I sound sound: apprehend, understand the intent.
Is not this bread—
Substantial bread—not painted?
But take heed,
You may be poisoned.
I am sure I am famished,
And famine, as the wise man says,
Gripes the guts as much as any mineral.
This may be treacle treacle: curative for poison sent to preserve me
After a long fast, or, be it viper's spittle spittle: saliva, in this case, venom ,
I'll run the hazard hazard: risk of loss or harm.
We are past all fear. I'll take part with ye.

Do. And now i'faith, how d'ye feel yourself?
Tibalt and Master, eating.
I find great ease in't. What's here?
Wine, and it be thy will,
Strong lusty lusty: pleasing, invigorating wine. Well, fools may talk

Of mithridate
mithridate: mixture considered to be a comprehensive remedy, cordials
cordials: comforting or reviving medicines or beverages, and elixirs
elixirs: liquid remedies for diseases,
But from my youth this was my only physic physic: curative.
Here's a color; what lady's cheek,
Though cerused cerused over: painted over, often in reference to medicinal ointments or cosmetics over, comes near it?
It sparkles too, hangs out diamonds—
Oh, my sweetheart, how I will hug thee
Again, and again! They are poor drunkards,
And not worth thy favors,
That number thy moist kisses thy moist kisses: sips of wine in these crystals. Tibalt drinks.
But monsieur,
Here are suckets suckets: sugar-preserved fruits and sweet dishes.
Tush Tush: contemptuous, impatient exclamation, boy's meat,
I am past it. Here's strong food fit for me— Tibalt drinks.
Nectar, old lad—mistress of merry hearts hearts: term of address often used in consideration of bravery,
Once more I am bold with you. Tibalt drinks.
Take heed, man.
Too much will breed distemper.
Hast thou lived at sea
The most part of thy life, where to be sober
While we have wine aboard is capital treason,
And dost thou preach sobriety? Tibalt drinks.
Prithee, forbearforbear: abstain,
We may offend in it. We know not for whom
It was provided.
I am sure for me. Therefore, footrafootra: exclamation meaning 'I care not'; often used contemptuously,
When I am full, let 'em hang me, I care not. Tibalt drinks.
(This has been his temper ever.)

See, provoking dishes, candied eryngoes
eryngoes: plants with aphrodisiac properties,
And potatoes—
I'll not touch 'em. I will drink,
But not a bit on a march not a bit on march: not a bite to eat from here on (Bourne).; I'll be an eunuch eunuch: castrated man, rather.

div.stage: Enter Albert, Aminta, Raymond, Lamure, Morillat, and Franville, severally.

lg.l: Who are these?
MarryMarry: expression of surprise used to emphasize what follows, who you will,
I keep my text here— Tibalt drinks.
Raymond!
Albert!
Away, I'll be drunk alone!
Keep off, rogues, or I'll belch ye into air.
Not a drop here. Tibalt drinks.
Dear brother, put not in your eyes such anger.
Those looks poisoned with fury shot at him
Reflect on me. Oh, brother, look milder, or
The crystal of his temperance
Will turn 'em on yourself The crystal ... on yourself: Albert's coolness and steadiness in the situation will act as a mirror to reflect Raymond's anger back at him.
Sir, I have sought ye long
To find your pardon. You have ploughed ploughed: figuratively tilled fields, but in this case more generally earned one's livelihood the ocean
To wreak your vengeance on me for the rape rape: abduction, not always with the intention of sexual violation
Of this fair virgin. Now, our fortune guides us
To meet on such hard terms that we need rather
A mutual pity of our present state
Than to expostulate of breaches past expostulate of breaches past: talk at length of former conflicts or transgressions
Which cannot be made up. And though it be
Far from your power to force me to confess
That I have done ye wrong, or such submission
Failing to make my peace, to vent your anger,
You being yourself slaved as I to others,
Yet for your sister's sake, her blessed sake,
In part of recompence of what she has suffered
For my rash folly, the contagion
Of my black actions catching hold upon
Her purer innocence, I crave your mercy,
And wish however several motives kept us
From being friends while we had hope to live,
Let death, which we expect and cannot fly fly: flee from,
End all contention.

Drink upon't, 'tis a good motion;
Tibalt offering wine.
Ratify Ratify: Formally sanction it in wine, and 'tis authentical authentical: legally valid. Tibalt drinks.
When I consider
The groundground: legal ground, reason of our long difference and look on
Our not-to-be-avoided miseries,
It doth beget in me—I know not how—
A soft religious tenderness which tells me,
Though we have many faults to answer for
Upon our own account, our fathers' crimes
Are in us punished. Oh, Albert, the course
They took to leave us rich was not honest,
Nor can that friendship last which virtue joins not.
When first they forced the industrious Portugals
From their plantations in the happy islands—
This is that I watch for—
And did omit no tyranny which men
InuredInured: Accustomed to spoilspoil: valuable goods, often referring to those acquired through piracy or conquest and mischief could inflict
On the grieved sufferers; when, by lawless rapinerapine: act of seizure by force
They reaped the harvest which their labors sowed,
And, not content to force 'em from their dwelling,
But laid for 'em at sea to ravishravish: carry off by force from 'em
The last remainder of their wealth, then, then
After a long pursuit, each doubting other
As guilty of the Portugals' escape,
They did begin to quarrel like ill men
(Forgive me, pietypiety: feeling of pity, devotion, and faithfulness, that I call 'em so)—
No longer love or correspondence holds
Than it is cemented with prey or profit—
Than did they turn those swords they oft had bloodied
With innocent gore upon their wretched selves
And paid the forfeit of their cruelty
Shown to Sebastian and his colony
By being fatal enemies to each other.
Thence grew Aminta's rape rape: abduction, not always with the intention of sexual violation, and my desire
To be revenged. And now observe the issue:
As they for spoil spoil: valuable goods, often referring to those acquired through piracy or conquest ever forgot compassion
To women (who should be exempted
From the extremities of a lawful war),
We now, young able men, are fallen into
The hands of women that, against the soft
Tenderness familiar to their sex,
Will show no mercy.
None, unless you show us
Our long lost husbands.
We are those Portugals you talked of—
StayStay: stop, halt,
I met upon the sea in a tall ship
Two Portugals, famished almost to death—
Our ship, by this wine!
And those the rogues that stole her
Left us to famish in the barren islands!
Some such tale they told me,
And something of a woman which, I find,
To be my sister.
Where are these men?
I left 'em,
Supposing they had deludeddeluded: deceived me with forged tales,
In the island where they said
They had lived many years the wretched owners
Of a huge mass of treasure.
The same men, and that the fatal muckfatal muck: referring to the treasure
We quarreled for.
They were Portugals, you say.
So they professed.
They may prove such men as may save your lives,
And so much I am taken with fair hope
That I will hazard hazard: run the risk life to be resolved on't.
How came you hither?
My ship lies by the river's mouth,
That can convey ye to these wretched men
Which you desire to see.
Back to your prisons,
And pray for the success. If they be those
Which I desire to find, you are safe.
If not, prepare to die tomorrow,
For the world cannot redeem ye.
However. We are armed
For either fortune.

div.stage: Exit all but Tibalt and Crocale.

lg.l: What must become of me, now
That I am not dismissed?
Oh, sir, I purpose
To have your company.
Take heed, wicked woman:
I am apt to mischief now.
You cannot be so unkind
To her that gives you liberty.
No, I shall be too kind, that's the devil on't.
I have had store store: collection of good wine, and when I am drunk
JoanJoan: generic name for any woman is a lady to me, and I shall
Lay about me like a lord—I feel strange motions.
Avoid me, temptation.
Come, sir, I'll help ye in.
What may that be
That moves upon the lake?
Still it draws nearer,
And now I plainly can discerndiscern: perceive, recognize it:
'Tis the French ship.
In it a woman
Who seems to invite us to her—
Still she calls with signs of love to hasten to her;
So lovely hope doth still appear
I feel nor age nor weakness.
Though it bring death—
To us 'tis comfort and deserves a meeting—
Or else Fortune tired with what we have suffered
And in it, overcome, as it may be,
Now sets a period to our misery.

div.stage: Enter Raymond, Albert, and Aminta, severally.

lg.l: What dreadful sounds are these?
Fit for a bloody feast.
It seems prepared
To kill our courages, ereere: before they divorce
Our souls and bodies.
But they that fearless fall
Deprive them of their triumph.

div.stage: Enter Rosella, Clarinda, Juletta, and Hippolita.

lg.l: See the FuriesFuries: from Greek mythology, female deities of vengeance
In their fullfull: i.e. more fully accomplished trim trim: dress of cruelty.
'Tis the last
Duty that I can pay to my dead lord.
Set out the altar—I myself will be
The priest—and boldly do those horrid rites
You shake to think on. Lead these captains nearer,
For they shall have the honor to fall first
To my Sebastian's ashes! And now, wretches,
As I am taught already that you are,
And lately by your free confession,
French pirates, and the sons of those I hate,
Even equal with the devil, hear with horror
What 'tis invites me to this cruel course
And what you are to suffer: no Amazons, we,
But women of Portugal, that must have from you
Sebastian and Nicusa! We are they
That groaned beneath your father's wrongs.
We are those wretched women
Their injuries pursued and overtook,
And from the sad remembrance of our losses,
We are taught to be cruel; when we were forced
From that sweet air we breathed in, by their rapine rapine: act of seizure by force,
And sought a place of being, as the seas
And winds conspired with their ill purposes
To load us with afflictions in a storm

That fell upon us, the two ships that brought us two ships that brought us: These two ships and what was on each is yet another instance in this play where gender roles are challenged. The treasures and other valuable belongings of the travelers were all aboard the men's ship, perhaps because these valuables would have been kept safe by them. Ironically, this proved to be quite the opposite; whereas the men landed on a desolate island, their crew eventually killing one another over the treasure, the women landed on the fertile island, and island containing all that they actually needed to survive. It was also said by Rosella that they became self-sufficient, learning to accomplish everything necessary for survival that they had once depended on the men for. This suggests that they did not, in the end, need men at all to thrive as a community, just as they did not require jewels or other material treasures.
To seek new fortunes in an unknown world,
Were severed. The one bore all the able men,
Our treasure, and our jewels; in the other,
We women were embarked, and fell upon,
After long tossing in the troubled main troubled main: main sea, open sea,
This pleasant island. But in a few months,
The men that did conduct us hither died.
We long before had given our husbands lost.
Remembering what we had suffered by the French,
We took a solemn oath never to admit
The cursed society of men. Necessity
Taught us those arts not usual to our sex,
And, the fertile earth yielding abundance to us,
We did resolve, thus shaped like Amazons,
To end our lives. But when you arrived here
And brought as presents to us our own jewels,
Those which were born in the other ship,
How can ye hope to 'scape our vengeance?
It boots not It boots not: It makes no difference, then, to swear our innocence?
Or that we never forced it from the owners?
Or that there are a remnant of that wreck,
And not far off?
All you affirm, I know,
Is but to win time. Therefore, prepare your throats—
The world shall not redeem ye—and that your cries
May find no entrance to our ears
To move pity in any, bid loud music sound
Their fatal knells. If ye have prayers, use 'em quickly
To any power will own ye—But ha! Enter Crocale, Sebastian, Nicusa, and Tibalt.
Who are these? What spectacles of misfortune?
Why are their looks
So full of joy and wonder?
Oh! Lay byLay by: Lay aside
These instruments of death, and welcome
To your arms what you durstdurst: archaic past tense of dare never hope to embrace:
This is Sebastian, this Nicusa, madam,
Preserved by miracle! Look up, dear sir,
And know your own Rosella! Be not lost
In wonder and amazement, or if nature
Can by instinct instruct you what it is
To be blessed with the name of father,
Freely enjoy it in this fair virgin.
Though my miseries
And many years of wantswants: shortages I have endured
May well deprive me of the memory
Of all joys past, ye looking on this building,
This ruined building of a heavenly form
In my Rosella, I must remember remember: remind: I am Sebastian.
Oh, my joys!
And here
I see a perfect model of thyself,
As thou wert when thy choice first made thee mine.
These cheeks and fronts fronts: forehead, here used plurally, though wrinkled now with time
Which art cannot restore, had equal pureness
Of natural white and red, and as much ravishingravishing: exciting pleasure or ecstasy,
Which by fair order and succession
I see descend on her. And may thy virtues
Wind into her form, and make her a perfect dowerdower: dowry, or money or property given to husband at time of marriage,
No part of thy sweet goodness wantingwanting: lacking to her.
I will not now, Rosella, ask thy fortunes,
Nor trouble thee with hearing mine;
Those shall hereafter serve to make glad hours
In their relation, all past wrongs forgot.
I am glad to see you, gentlemen, but most,
That it is in my power to save your lives—
You saved ours when we were near starved at sea—
And I despair not, for if she be mine,

Rosella can deny Sebastian nothing Rosella ... nothing: Sebastian reclaims his wife, after also proclaiming that Clarinda will be a good wife and that she will take on Rosella's virtues. Jane O'Brien discusses the trajectory of a woman's life in the period: "Whether they're mothers, ingenues or unruly woman, they are all women discovering how to find their way in the world. And it's a pretty tough world." In a way, Clarinda must now, like her mother, "find [her] way in the world," but in a form that is only granted to her by her father. So, while she may have freedom, she may also lack it, both in this scene and, presumably, throughout her life..
She does give up herself,
Her power and joys and all, to you,
To be discharged of 'em as too burdensome;
Welcome in any shape.
Sir, in your looks
I read your suitsuit: legal pursuit of my Clarinda; she is yours.
To Aminta. And, lady, if it be in me to confirm
Your hopes to this bravebrave: fine, worthy gentleman,

Presume I am your servant. Sir ... servant: The dialogue in this speech implies there will be a double wedding (Clarinda marrying Raymond and Aminta marrying Albert), but no actual marriage ceremony occurs in the play. This is somewhat typical of seventeenth century comedies, where marriage is promised but not enacted. As a result, the play closes with a seemingly optimistic future, but one that has not yet come about, making the play's ending more ambiguous.
We thank you, sir.
Oh, happy hour!
Oh, my dear Aminta,
Now all our fears are ended.
Here I fix: she's mettle mettle: spirited, of strong character,
Steel to the back, and will cut my leaden dagger
If not used with discretion.
You are still no changeling changeling: changeable or fickle person—
Nay, all look cheerfully, for none shall be
Denied their lawful wishes. When awhile
We have here refreshed ourselves, we'll return
To our several homes, and well that voyage ends,
That makes of deadly enemies faithful friends.
